<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage';
	}
</script>

	<title>Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia</title>
	<meta name="description" content="A first in our telemetry: Chinese APT Stately Taurus uses Visual Studio Code to maintain a reverse shell in victims&#039; environments for Southeast Asian espionage. A first in our telemetry: Chinese APT Stately Taurus uses Visual Studio Code to maintain a reverse shell in victims&#039; environments for Southeast Asian espionage." />

	<meta property="og:title" content="Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia" />
	<meta property="og:description" content="A first in our telemetry: Chinese APT Stately Taurus uses Visual Studio Code to maintain a reverse shell in victims&#039; environments for Southeast Asian espionage. A first in our telemetry: Chinese APT Stately Taurus uses Visual Studio Code to maintain a reverse shell in victims&#039; environments for Southeast Asian espionage." />

<meta property="og:likes" content="0"/>
<meta property="og:readtime" content="9"/>
<meta property="og:views" content="15,354"/>
<meta property="og:date_created" content="September 6, 2024 at 3:00 PM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="2416"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Actor Groups"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Tom Fakterman"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="Advanced Persistent Threat,China,DLL Sideloading,Dropbox,Espionage,Government,Microsoft Visual Studio,Mimikatz,ShadowPad,TA416,ToneShell,VSCode"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia","name":"Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia","description":"A first in our telemetry: Chinese APT Stately Taurus uses Visual Studio Code to maintain a reverse shell in victims' environments for Southeast Asian espionage.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage\/","datePublished":"September 6, 2024","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nUnit 42 researchers recently found that Stately Taurus abused the popular Visual Studio Code software in espionage operations targeting government entities in Southeast Asia. Stately Taurus is a Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) group that carries out cyberespionage attacks.\r\n\r\nThis threat actor used Visual Studio Code\u2019s embedded reverse shell feature to gain a foothold in target networks. This is a relatively new technique that a security researcher discovered in 2023. According to our telemetry, this is the first time a threat actor used it in the wild.\r\n\r\nWe assess that this campaign is a direct continuation of a previously reported campaign that we attributed with moderate-high confidence to Stately Taurus. We come to this conclusion based on consideration of the TTPs, timeline and victimology targeting government entities in Southeast Asia.\r\n\r\nWe will also discuss a connection between the Stately Taurus activity and a second cluster of activity occurring simultaneously in the same targeted environment that leveraged the ShadowPad backdoor.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive better protection against threats discussed in this article through the following products and services, which we detail further in the Conclusion section:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering\r\n \tAdvanced DNS Security\r\n \tCortex XDR\r\n \tCortex XSIAM\r\n \tPrisma Cloud Compute\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nChina, DLL Sideloading\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Rare Use of Visual Studio Code Abuse\r\nOne of the novel techniques Stately Taurus used to bypass security protections leverages Visual Studio Code\u2019s embedded reverse shell feature to execute arbitrary code and deliver additional payloads. Truvis Thornton described this technique in a Medium post in September 2023, but this is the first time we\u2019ve observed threat actors abusing this technique in the wild.\r\n\r\nTo abuse Visual Studio Code for malicious purposes, an attacker can use the portable version of code.exe (the executable file for Visual Studio Code), or an already installed version of the software. By running the command code.exe tunnel, an attacker receives a link that requires them to log into GitHub with their own account.\r\n\r\nAfter logging in, the attacker is redirected to a Visual Studio Code web environment that is connected to the compromised machine. They are then permitted to execute commands and scripts, and to create new files on the infected machine.\r\n\r\nStately Taurus used this technique to deliver malware to infected environments, perform reconnaissance and exfiltrate sensitive data. To establish constant access to the reverse shell, the attacker created persistence for a script named startcode.bat using a scheduled task that is responsible for starting the shell.\r\n\r\nFigure 1 shows the process tree for code.exe abuse in Cortex XDR.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136604\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Process tree of the code.exe abuse in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\nThe Connection to Stately Taurus\r\nIn September 2023, we discussed a campaign that was attributed to Stately Taurus, which leveraged the ToneShell backdoor as one of its main tools. During this campaign, Stately Taurus used ToneShell to archive files for exfiltration, protecting the RAR archives with a unique password.\r\n\r\nThe password was 13 characters long, using upper and lower case letters as well as digits. By tracking this unique password in our telemetry, we were able to find additional Stately Taurus activity in the same targeted environment.\r\n\r\nWe concluded that this campaign is a continuation of the Stately Taurus activity we reported in this campaign due to the following factors:\r\n\r\n \tThe use of the same unique password\r\n \tAdditional TTPs\r\n \tTimeline\r\n \tVictimology targeting governmental entities in Southeast Asia\r\n\r\nFigure 2 presents the connections between the components of Stately Taurus.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136606\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Connections between different components of the campaign and the unique Stately Taurus password.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nStately Taurus (aka Mustang Panda, BRONZE PRESIDENT, RedDelta, Luminous Moth, Earth Preta and Camaro Dragon) has been operating since at least 2012. Stately Taurus is a Chinese APT group that routinely conducts cyberespionage campaigns targeting government entities, as well as religious and other nongovernmental organizations across Europe and Asia.\r\nAdditional TTPs Related to the Stately Taurus Cluster\r\n\r\n \tSshd.exe: The attacker used OpenSSH (sshd.exe) to execute commands, transfer files and spread across the environment as shown in Figure 3. OpenSSH allows the user to connect to a remote machine via SSH.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136608\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. Sshd.exe used for lateral movement shown in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n \tSharpNBTScan: The attackers used SharpNBTScan (renamed as win1.exe) to perform scanning in the environment\r\n \tListeners.bat: On some occasions the attackers used a batch file named Listeners.bat to archive files for exfiltration\r\n\r\nExfiltration\r\nAs part of this operation, Stately Taurus attempted to exfiltrate sensitive information from different machines. The attacker executed rar.exe remotely via SMB. Next, they tried to iterate and archive all drives from A-Z on remote machines, as shown in Figure 4.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136610\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 4. Attacker uses code.exe to archive folders from remote machines shown in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nTo exfiltrate the archived files, the attacker used curl to upload the files to Dropbox, which is a legitimate file hosting service. The attacker used this service to blend in and exfiltrate the data without drawing too much attention.\r\n\r\nStately Taurus used the same technique previously, as described in our previous article. Figure 5 below shows the command line the attacker used for exfiltration.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136612\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 5. Data exfiltration using Dropbox.[\/caption]\r\nThe Connection to a ShadowPad Activity\r\nWhile investigating the Stately Taurus cluster, we observed another cluster of activity in the same environment, occurring simultaneously and at times even on the same endpoints. This cluster of activity used the ShadowPad backdoor as its main tool, from which attackers launched other activity. ShadowPad is modular malware that has been in use by multiple Chinese threat actors since at least 2017.\r\n\r\nThe connection between these two clusters includes the following overlap:\r\n\r\n \tFollowing the origins of Listeners.bat (used in the Stately Taurus cluster) on an infected machine, we observed that the same network session that wrote Listeners.bat, wrote additional files and malware including the ShadowPad backdoor.\r\n \tListeners.bat also used the same unique password that the ToneShell backdoor from the Stately Taurus cluster used. Figure 6 depicts this connection.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136614\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 6. The observed connection between Listener.bat of Stately Taurus and ShadowPad.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs of mid-August 2024, it is unclear whether these two clusters originated from the same threat actor. The fact that the two files originated from the same network session might indicate a connection between the ShadowPad activity to the VSCode activity linked to Stately Taurus.\r\n\r\nThere could also be other possible scenarios to explain this connection. For example, it could be a joint effort between two Chinese APT groups or perhaps two different groups piggybacking on each other\u2019s access.\r\nThe ShadowPad Activity\r\nOne of the main tools used in this cluster is the ShadowPad backdoor.\r\n\r\nIn the cluster described in this section, the attacker abused the legitimate process imecmnt.exe via DLL sideloading to load the ShadowPad module (imjp14k.dll). Imecmnt.exe is a Microsoft Office Input Method Editor (IME) component.\r\n\r\nTo keep ShadowPad running on victim machines, the attacker created persistence via a service. These service names are listed in the Indicators of Compromise section below.\r\n\r\nFigure 7 shows how ShadowPad (imecmnt.exe renamed as update.exe to appear less suspicious) spawns and injects code into wmplayer.exe, which in turn spawns and injects code into dllhost.exe.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136616\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 7. ShadowPad infection in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFurther TTPs related to the ShadowPad activity can be found in the Appendix section of the blog.\r\nConclusion\r\nIn this follow-up post, we shared new TTPs the Stately Taurus APT group used in an espionage campaign that targeted government entities in Southeast Asia. One of the most noteworthy techniques that we observed in this campaign is the abuse of Visual Studio Code for executing malicious code and gaining a foothold in the infected environment. According to our telemetry, this is the first time attackers have used this technique in the wild.\r\n\r\nIn addition, we examined a connection we encountered between the Stately Taurus activity cluster and another cluster that used the ShadowPad backdoor in the same environment. As of mid-August 2024, the connection between these two clusters remains uncertain.\r\n\r\nBased on the forensic evidence and timeline, one could conclude that these two clusters originated from the same threat actor (Stately Taurus). However, there could be other possible explanations that can account for this connection, such as a collaborative effort between two Chinese APT threat actors.\r\n\r\nWe encourage organizations to leverage our findings to inform the deployment of protective measures to defend against this threat group.\r\nProtections and Mitigations\r\nFor Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire cloud-delivered malware analysis service accurately identifies the known samples as malicious.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify IP addresses associated with this group as malicious.\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM are designed to:\r\n\r\n \tPrevent the execution of known malicious malware and prevent the execution of unknown malware using Behavioral Threat Protection as well as machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.\r\n \tProtect against credential gathering tools and techniques using the new Credential Gathering Protection available from Cortex XDR 3.4.\r\n \tProtect from threat actors dropping and executing commands from web shells using Anti-Webshell Protection, newly released in Cortex XDR 3.4.\r\n \tProtect against exploitation of different vulnerabilities including ProxyShell and ProxyLogon using the Anti-Exploitation modules as well as Behavioral Threat Protection.\r\n \tDetect post-exploit activity, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics, through Cortex XDR Pro.\r\n\r\n\r\n \tPrisma Cloud Compute and Advanced WildFire integration can help detect and prevent malicious execution of the malware within Windows-based VM, container and serverless cloud infrastructure.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\nStately Taurus Cluster\r\nSharpNBTScan\r\n\r\n \t506fc87c8c96fef1d2df24b0ba44c8116a9001ca5a7d7e9c01dc3940a664acb0\r\n\r\nListeners.bat\r\n\r\n \taa2c0de121ae738ce44727456d97434faff21fc69219e964e1e2d2f1ca16b1c5\r\n \t8fdac78183ff18de0c07b10e8d787326691d7fb1f63b3383471312b74918c39f\r\n \t39ceb73bcfd1f674a9b72a03476a9de997867353172c2bf6dde981c5b3ad512a\r\n\r\nShadowpad Cluster\r\n\r\nShadowPad\r\n\r\n \t0f11b6dd8ff972a2f8cb7798b1a0a8cd10afadcea201541c93ef0ab9b141c184\r\n \t456e4dae82a12bcda0506a750eac93bf79cc056b8aad09ec74878c90fd67bd8f\r\n \tbdadcd2842ed7ba8a21df7910a0acc15f8b0ca9d0b91bebb49f09a906ae217e6\r\n\r\nShadowPad C2\r\n\r\n \t216.83.40[.]84\r\n\r\nShadowPad Service Names\r\n\r\n \tWindowsMailServices\r\n \ttest12\r\n \tWindowsEdgeUpdateServices\r\n \tWindowsMailServices\r\n \tJavaservice\r\n \tWindowsEdgeUpdateServices\r\n\r\nMimikatz\r\n\r\n \tac34e1fb4288f8ad996b821c89b8cd82a61ed02f629b60fff9eb050aaf49fc31\r\n\r\nIn-Swor\r\n\r\n \t440e7bce4760b367b46754a70f480941a38cd6cd4c00c56bbaeb80b9c149afb1\r\n \t5bfc45f7fce27d05e753a61dde5fab623efff3e4df56fb6a0cf178a0b11909ce\r\n \tfb0c4db0011ee19742d7d8bd0558d8ee8be2ef23c4c61a3e80a34fba6c96f3ff\r\n \t965dd0b255f05ff012d2f152e973e09ceb9e95b6239dc820c8ac4d4492255472\r\n\r\nLsass-dump-main\r\n\r\n \tacedfe9c662c2666787cbbf8d3a0225863bab2c239777594b003381244ed81ba\r\n\r\nTscan\r\n\r\n \tcca63c929f2f59894ea2204408f67fc1bff774bb7164fde7f42d0111df9461bd\r\n\r\nLaZagne\r\n\r\n \t3cc5ee93a9ba1fc57389705283b760c8bd61f35e9398bbfa3210e2becf6d4b05\r\n\r\nShadowPad Cluster Attacker C2\r\n\r\n \t185.132.125[.]72\r\n\r\nAppendix: Further Activity Related to ShadowPad\r\nThe threat actor used the following tools to perform reconnaissance in victim environments:\r\n\r\n \tTscan: The attacker used a variation of the open-source tool fscan, which they named Tscan. Tscan\u2019s capabilities include scanning, password spraying and command execution.\r\n\r\nFigure 8 shows the Tscan banner and help menu, and Figure 9 shows Tscan (ts.exe) being detected for performing a port scan.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136618\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"360\"] Figure 8. Tscan banner and help menu snippet.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136620\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"800\"] Figure 9. Tscan detected for performing a port scan in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n \tADExplorer64.exe: The attacker attempted to use the utility AD Explorer on the victim\u2019s Active Directory. This tool allows its user to easily query an Active Directory database.\r\n\r\nCredential Theft\r\nThe attacker attempted to use different methods to dump credentials. The following is a list of each method:\r\n\r\n \tIn-Swor: The attacker attempted to use an open-source tool named In-Swor to execute Mimikatz, as shown in Figure 10. In-Swor appears to have a Chinese-speaking author and it is described as a penetration tool meant to bypass antivirus products.\r\n\r\nAccording to the tool\u2019s GitHub page, the current modules that are available for the tool include: mimikatz, frpc, bypassuac, elevation, killAV and fscan.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136622\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 10. In-Swor (wk.exe) prevented attempting to load Mimikatz in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n \tMimikatz: The attacker attempted to dump credentials from memory using the known credential-harvesting tool MimiKatz (named setup1.exe)\r\n \tLaZagne: The threat actor attempted to use the LaZagne tool to access passwords in infected systems. LaZagne is an open-source tool used to recover stored passwords from systems.\r\n \tLsass-dump-main: To retrieve passwords, the threat actor attempted to use what appeared to be a custom tool to dump the memory of the lsass.exe process to disk. Figure 11 shows the output of this tool.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136624\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 11. Output from the Lsass-dump-main tool.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n \tStealing the NTDS.dit File: To steal Active Directory data, the attacker attempted to steal NTDS.dit as shown in Figure 12. NTDS.dit is an Active Directory database that stores information about user objects, groups, group membership and (most importantly) password hashes.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136626\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 12. Alert for dump of NTDS.dit in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nTo steal the NTDS.dit file, the threat actor used Vssadmin to create a volume shadow copy on the Domain Controller, which allowed the attacker to access the NTDS.dit file. Next, the attacker dumped the SYSTEM hive from the registry, which contains the boot key that is required to decrypt the NTDS.dit file.\r\n\r\n \tPSEXESVC.exe: The attacker used the popular PsExec utility for lateral movement across the victim\u2019s environment. PsExec allows the execution of processes on remote systems.\r\n \tWindows Management Instrumentation (WMI): The threat actor used WMI to execute remote processes in the environment. WMI allows the execution of processes on local and remote systems.\r\n","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/09\/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1920x900-1-300x300.png","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Tom Fakterman"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<style id='co-authors-plus-coauthors-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow [class*=wp-block-co-authors-plus]{display:inline}

</style>
<style id='co-authors-plus-avatar-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar :where(img){height:auto;max-width:100%;vertical-align:bottom}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow .wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar :where(img){vertical-align:middle}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar:is(.alignleft,.alignright){display:table}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar.aligncenter{display:table;margin-inline:auto}

</style>
<style id='co-authors-plus-image-style-inline-css'>

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-136600 single-format-standard no-sidebar">

      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>

<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

          <div class="l-container">

              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" title="Threat Actor Groups" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Actor Groups">Threat Actor Groups</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" title="Malware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:breadcrumb:Malware">Malware</a></li> </ul>

data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:DLL Sideloading" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dll-sideloading/">DLL Sideloading</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:Dropbox" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dropbox/">Dropbox</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:Espionage" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/espionage/">Espionage</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:Government" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/government/">Government</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:Microsoft Visual Studio" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/microsoft-visual-studio/">Microsoft Visual Studio</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:Mimikatz" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mimikatz/">Mimikatz</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:ShadowPad" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/shadowpad/">ShadowPad</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:TA416" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/ta416/">TA416</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:ToneShell" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/toneshell/">ToneShell</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:VSCode" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/vscode/">VSCode</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>
                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-136600-_xw19ouqh7ayq"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers recently found that Stately Taurus abused the popular Visual Studio Code software in espionage operations targeting government entities in Southeast Asia. Stately Taurus is a Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) group that carries out cyberespionage attacks.</p>
<p>This threat actor used Visual Studio Code’s embedded reverse shell feature to gain a foothold in target networks. This is a relatively new technique that <a href="https://medium.com/@truvis.thornton/visual-studio-code-embedded-reverse-shell-and-how-to-block-create-sentinel-detection-and-add-e864ebafaf6d" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a security researcher discovered</a> in 2023. According to our telemetry, this is the first time a threat actor used it in the wild.</p>
<p>We assess that this campaign is a direct continuation of a <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-attacks-se-asian-government/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previously reported campaign </a>that we attributed with moderate-high confidence to Stately Taurus. We come to this conclusion based on consideration of the TTPs, timeline and victimology targeting government entities in Southeast Asia.</p>
<p>We will also discuss a connection between the Stately Taurus activity and a second cluster of activity occurring simultaneously in the same targeted environment that leveraged the ShadowPad backdoor.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive better protection against threats discussed in this article through the following products and services, which we detail further in the Conclusion section:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/blog/prisma-cloud/prisma-cloud-and-wildfire-integration/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XSIAM</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/prisma-cloud-compute-edition-aag" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud Compute</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/china/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>China</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dll-sideloading/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DLL Sideloading</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_erks0at3jq2"></a>The Rare Use of Visual Studio Code Abuse</h2>
<p>One of the novel techniques Stately Taurus used to bypass security protections leverages Visual Studio Code’s embedded reverse shell feature to execute arbitrary code and deliver additional payloads. Truvis Thornton described this technique in a <a href="https://medium.com/@truvis.thornton/visual-studio-code-embedded-reverse-shell-and-how-to-block-create-sentinel-detection-and-add-e864ebafaf6d" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Medium post </a>in September 2023, but this is the first time we’ve observed threat actors abusing this technique in the wild.</p>
<p>To abuse Visual Studio Code for malicious purposes, an attacker can use the portable version of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">code.exe</span> (the executable file for Visual Studio Code), or an already installed version of the software. By running the command <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">code.exe tunnel</span>, an attacker receives a link that requires them to log into GitHub with their own account.</p>
<p>After logging in, the attacker is redirected to a Visual Studio Code web environment that is connected to the compromised machine. They are then permitted to execute commands and scripts, and to create new files on the infected machine.</p>
<p>Stately Taurus used this technique to deliver malware to infected environments, perform reconnaissance and exfiltrate sensitive data. To establish constant access to the reverse shell, the attacker created persistence for a script named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">startcode.bat</span> using a scheduled task that is responsible for starting the shell.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows the process tree for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">code.exe</span> abuse in Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136604" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136604" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136604" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-391402-136600-1.png" alt="Flowchart showing a sequence of executable files in Cortex XDR. The process starts with an EXE file, leading through various nodes. Each file is connected by blue lines indicating the flow of processes." width="900" height="411" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-391402-136600-1.png 1331w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-391402-136600-1-786x359.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-391402-136600-1-768x351.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136604" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Process tree of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">code.exe</span> abuse in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_t0p9rgmqno95"></a>The Connection to Stately Taurus</h2>
<p>In September 2023, we discussed a campaign that was <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-attacks-se-asian-government/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">attributed to Stately Taurus</a>, which leveraged the <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.toneshell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ToneShell</a> backdoor as one of its main tools. During this campaign, Stately Taurus used ToneShell to archive files for exfiltration, protecting the RAR archives with a unique password.</p>
<p>The password was 13 characters long, using upper and lower case letters as well as digits. By tracking this unique password in our telemetry, we were able to find additional Stately Taurus activity in the same targeted environment.</p>
<p>We concluded that this campaign is a continuation of the Stately Taurus activity we reported in this campaign due to the following factors:</p>
<ul>
<li>The use of the same unique password</li>
<li>Additional TTPs</li>
<li>Timeline</li>
<li>Victimology targeting governmental entities in Southeast Asia</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 2 presents the connections between the components of Stately Taurus.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136606" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136606" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136606" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-394415-136600-2.png" alt="A flowchart comparing two attack campaigns. On top is the previous campaign using ToneShell by Stately Taurus with a unique password. This unique password was used in a current campaign that also utilized the same unique password. Other elements of the current campaign include a BAT file, abuse of VSCode and an EXE file. Logo lockup for Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42. " width="900" height="570" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-394415-136600-2.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-394415-136600-2-694x440.png 694w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-394415-136600-2-1104x700.png 1104w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-394415-136600-2-768x487.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-394415-136600-2-1536x974.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136606" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Connections between different components of the campaign and the unique Stately Taurus password.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-actor-groups-tracked-by-palo-alto-networks-unit-42/#:~:text=Stately%20Taurus%20is%20a%20China%2Dbased%20cyberespionage%20threat%20actor%20that%20was%20first%20observed%20in%202017%2C%20but%20they%20may%20have%20been%20conducting%20operations%20since%20at%20least%202012" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Stately Taurus</a> (aka Mustang Panda, BRONZE PRESIDENT, RedDelta, Luminous Moth, Earth Preta and Camaro Dragon) has been operating since at least 2012. Stately Taurus is a Chinese APT group that routinely conducts cyberespionage campaigns targeting <a href="https://www.darkreading.com/endpoint-security/group-tied-to-china-s-mustang-panda-targets-european-governments-with-smugx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">government entities</a>, as well as <a href="https://www.recordedfuture.com/blog/reddelta-targets-catholic-organizations" target="_blank" rel="noopener">religious and other nongovernmental</a> organizations across <a href="https://www.darkreading.com/endpoint-security/group-tied-to-china-s-mustang-panda-targets-european-governments-with-smugx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Europe</a> and <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-attacks-se-asian-government/#post-130090-_z4kcskcif3h6" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Asia</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_k0lcm922t33m"></a>Additional TTPs Related to the Stately Taurus Cluster</h2>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><strong>Sshd.exe</strong></span>: The attacker used <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/openssh/openssh_server_configuration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OpenSSH</a> (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sshd.exe</span>) to execute commands, transfer files and spread across the environment as shown in Figure 3. OpenSSH allows the user to connect to a remote machine via SSH.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_136608" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136608" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136608" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-397801-136600-3.png" alt="Diagram in Cortex XDR. Shows sshd.exe process on two devices connected via port 445 with an alert symbol indicating unusual SMB Traffic from a non-standard process. Descriptive text notes sshd.exe communicating over port 445. Some of the information is redacted. " width="900" height="471" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-397801-136600-3.png 1962w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-397801-136600-3-786x411.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-397801-136600-3-1339x700.png 1339w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-397801-136600-3-768x402.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-397801-136600-3-1536x803.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136608" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sshd.exe</span> used for lateral movement shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<ul>
<li><strong>SharpNBTScan: </strong>The attackers used <a href="https://github.com/BronzeTicket/SharpNBTScan" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SharpNBTScan</a> (renamed as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">win1.exe</span>) to perform scanning in the environment</li>
<li><strong>Listeners.bat</strong>: On some occasions the attackers used a batch file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Listeners.bat</span> to archive files for exfiltration</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-136600-_vawab6tg40c4"></a>Exfiltration</h3>
<p>As part of this operation, Stately Taurus attempted to exfiltrate sensitive information from different machines. The attacker executed <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rar.exe</span> remotely via <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_Message_Block" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SMB</a></span>. Next, they tried to iterate and archive all drives from A-Z on remote machines, as shown in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136610" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136610" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136610" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-402497-136600-4.png" alt="Flowchart in Cortex XDR. Some of the information is redacted. The process tree ends in several RAR files. " width="900" height="296" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-402497-136600-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-402497-136600-4-786x258.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-402497-136600-4-1920x631.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-402497-136600-4-768x252.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-402497-136600-4-1536x505.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136610" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Attacker uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">code.exe</span> to archive folders from remote machines shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<p>To exfiltrate the archived files, the attacker used <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_Message_Block" target="_blank" rel="noopener">curl</a></span> to upload the files to Dropbox, which is a legitimate file hosting service. The attacker used this service to blend in and exfiltrate the data without drawing too much attention.</p>
<p>Stately Taurus used the same technique previously, as described in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-attacks-se-asian-government/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">our previous article</a>. Figure 5 below shows the command line the attacker used for exfiltration.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136612" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136612" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136612" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-407114-136600-5.png" alt="Image displaying a line of code example for using cURL to upload a file to Dropbox." width="700" height="87" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-407114-136600-5.png 1139w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-407114-136600-5-786x98.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-407114-136600-5-768x96.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136612" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Data exfiltration using Dropbox.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_6ptevot7jgmn"></a>The Connection to a ShadowPad Activity</h2>
<p>While investigating the Stately Taurus cluster, we observed another cluster of activity in the same environment, occurring simultaneously and at times even on the same endpoints. This cluster of activity used the <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.shadowpad" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ShadowPad backdoor</a> as its main tool, from which attackers launched other activity. ShadowPad is modular malware that has been in use by multiple Chinese threat actors <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">since at least 2017</a>.</p>
<p>The connection between these two clusters includes the following overlap:</p>
<ul>
<li>Following the origins of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Listeners.bat</span> (used in the Stately Taurus cluster) on an infected machine, we observed that the same network session that wrote <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Listeners.bat</span>, wrote additional files and malware including the ShadowPad backdoor.</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Listeners.bat</span> also used the same unique password that the ToneShell backdoor from the Stately Taurus cluster used. Figure 6 depicts this connection.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_136614" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136614" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136614" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-409505-136600-6.png" alt="Diagram of a network session showing data exchange between Host A and Host B, involving files written from Host A to Host B on the same network session. Highlighted are entities 'Listeners.Taurus Cluster' and 'ShadowPad' corresponding to the files exchanged. Includes logos for Palo Alto Networks and UNIT 42 at the bottom." width="600" height="406" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-409505-136600-6.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-409505-136600-6-650x440.png 650w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-409505-136600-6-1034x700.png 1034w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-409505-136600-6-768x520.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-409505-136600-6-1536x1040.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136614" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. The observed connection between <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Listener.bat</span> of Stately Taurus and ShadowPad.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As of mid-August 2024, it is unclear whether these two clusters originated from the same threat actor. The fact that the two files originated from the same network session might indicate a connection between the ShadowPad activity to the VSCode activity linked to Stately Taurus.</p>
<p>There could also be other possible scenarios to explain this connection. For example, it could be a joint effort between two Chinese APT groups or perhaps two different groups piggybacking on each other’s access.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136600-_5vrn1l2c3zs3"></a>The ShadowPad Activity</h3>
<p>One of the main tools used in this cluster is the <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.shadowpad" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ShadowPad backdoor</a>.</p>
<p>In the cluster described in this section, the attacker abused the legitimate process <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">imecmnt.exe</span> via DLL sideloading to load the ShadowPad module (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">imjp14k.dll</span>). <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Imecmnt.exe</span> is a <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/apps/design/input/input-method-editors" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Microsoft Office Input Method Editor (IME)</a> component.</p>
<p>To keep ShadowPad running on victim machines, the attacker created persistence via a service. These service names are listed in the <a href="#post-136600-_ydqdbjg0dngh">Indicators of Compromise</a> section below.</p>
<p>Figure 7 shows how ShadowPad (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">imecmnt.exe</span> renamed as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update.exe</span> to appear less suspicious) spawns and injects code into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wmplayer.exe</span>, which in turn spawns and injects code into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dllhost.exe</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136616" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136616" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136616" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-412946-136600-7.png" alt="Flowchart image displaying three processes. The boxes include descriptions and additional details like alert names and tags. A box displays the product, description and original name. " width="700" height="343" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-412946-136600-7.png 1032w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-412946-136600-7-786x385.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-412946-136600-7-768x377.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136616" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. ShadowPad infection in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Further TTPs related to the ShadowPad activity can be found in the Appendix section of the blog.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_2qdstc8yyfzj"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>In this follow-up post, we shared new TTPs the Stately Taurus APT group used in an espionage campaign that targeted government entities in Southeast Asia. One of the most noteworthy techniques that we observed in this campaign is the abuse of Visual Studio Code for executing malicious code and gaining a foothold in the infected environment. According to our telemetry, this is the first time attackers have used this technique in the wild.</p>
<p>In addition, we examined a connection we encountered between the Stately Taurus activity cluster and another cluster that used the ShadowPad backdoor in the same environment. As of mid-August 2024, the connection between these two clusters remains uncertain.</p>
<p>Based on the forensic evidence and timeline, one could conclude that these two clusters originated from the same threat actor (Stately Taurus). However, there could be other possible explanations that can account for this connection, such as a collaborative effort between two Chinese APT threat actors.</p>
<p>We encourage organizations to leverage our findings to inform the deployment of protective measures to defend against this threat group.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_mf3k1d3b3om7"></a><strong>Protections and Mitigations</strong></h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> cloud-delivered malware analysis service accurately identifies the known samples as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify IP addresses associated with this group as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> are designed to:
<ul>
<li>Prevent the execution of known malicious malware and prevent the execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/guides/cortex-xdr-endpoint-protection-solution-guide">Behavioral Threat Protection</a> as well as machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
<li>Protect against credential gathering tools and techniques using the new Credential Gathering Protection available from Cortex XDR 3.4.</li>
<li>Protect from threat actors dropping and executing commands from web shells using Anti-Webshell Protection, newly released in Cortex XDR 3.4.</li>
<li>Protect against exploitation of different vulnerabilities including ProxyShell and ProxyLogon using the Anti-Exploitation modules as well as Behavioral Threat Protection.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/analytics-alerts-by-required-data-source" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Detect post-exploit activity</a>, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics, through Cortex XDR Pro.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/prisma-cloud-compute-edition-aag" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud Compute</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/blog/prisma-cloud/prisma-cloud-and-wildfire-integration/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> integration can help detect and prevent malicious execution of the malware within Windows-based VM, container and serverless cloud infrastructure.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-136600-_ydqdbjg0dngh"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-136600-_olh7p8ovu2b8"></a><br />
Stately Taurus Cluster</h3>
<h4>SharpNBTScan</h4>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">506fc87c8c96fef1d2df24b0ba44c8116a9001ca5a7d7e9c01dc3940a664acb0</span></li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-136600-_n8afubt094kd"></a>Listeners.bat</h4>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">aa2c0de121ae738ce44727456d97434faff21fc69219e964e1e2d2f1ca16b1c5</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8fdac78183ff18de0c07b10e8d787326691d7fb1f63b3383471312b74918c39f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">39ceb73bcfd1f674a9b72a03476a9de997867353172c2bf6dde981c5b3ad512a</span></li>
</ul>
<h3>Shadowpad Cluster</h3>
<h4><a id="post-136600-_tla80wbuembh"></a><br />
ShadowPad</h4>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0f11b6dd8ff972a2f8cb7798b1a0a8cd10afadcea201541c93ef0ab9b141c184</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">456e4dae82a12bcda0506a750eac93bf79cc056b8aad09ec74878c90fd67bd8f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bdadcd2842ed7ba8a21df7910a0acc15f8b0ca9d0b91bebb49f09a906ae217e6</span></li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-136600-_gahgc45wkobi"></a>ShadowPad C2</h4>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">216.83.40[.]84</span></li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-136600-_rmzc0s3sj2rn"></a>ShadowPad Service Names</h4>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WindowsMailServices</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">test12</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WindowsEdgeUpdateServices</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WindowsMailServices</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Javaservice</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WindowsEdgeUpdateServices</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-136600-_30g4vg33fbi0"></a>Mimikatz</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ac34e1fb4288f8ad996b821c89b8cd82a61ed02f629b60fff9eb050aaf49fc31</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-136600-_cy8mr8otch89"></a>In-Swor</h3>
<ul>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5bfc45f7fce27d05e753a61dde5fab623efff3e4df56fb6a0cf178a0b11909ce</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fb0c4db0011ee19742d7d8bd0558d8ee8be2ef23c4c61a3e80a34fba6c96f3ff</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">965dd0b255f05ff012d2f152e973e09ceb9e95b6239dc820c8ac4d4492255472</span></li>
</ul>

<ul>
